overview.short: Citrobacter species are Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic rods within the Enterobacterales, commonly found in the intestinal tract and environment.
overview.clinical_context: Associated with opportunistic infections including urinary tract, bloodstream, neonatal meningitis, and intra-abdominal infections.

field_notes.Lactose Fermentation: Often delayed or variable on MacConkey Agar.
field_notes.H2S: Some species produce H2S, which may cause confusion with Salmonella.
field_notes.Indole: Indole reactions vary by species and are useful at the species level.

key_differentiators.notes: MR positivity helps separate Citrobacter from VP-positive Enterobacterales.
Possible H2S production differentiates Citrobacter from E. coli.
Delayed or absent lactose fermentation helps exclude E. coli.

common_confusions.reason: Shared H2S production and Enterobacterales profile.
Overlapping sugar fermentation and citrate positivity.

when_to_question_identification: Strong VP positivity suggests Enterobacter or Klebsiella.
Absence of nitrate reduction argues against Citrobacter.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Helps separate Citrobacter from related genera.
Standard biochemical panel for Enterobacterales identification.
Provides rapid and reliable species-level identification.
